column4: in case anyone answered my question while i was timing out, please repaste it
because now i have the issue again, and would really like to know why it is happening

i don't quite get this, i switched from putty to SecureCRT recently for my windows ssh client, as it got the best ratings. but now with this client, if my connection dies, all processing running in ssh sessions continue in the background, which forces me to kill them manually later to free listening ports and stuff... does anyone have any idea why this would be happening?
when the ssh session dies, so do all processes that it is running
it breaks ssh's expected behaviour

how is it possible to disconnect from a SSHd, without the session dying? i have always assumed this is impossible, but since i now see it is possible, i'd like to know how it can be done, and if it is possible to reconnect to the same session again
but i guess maybe a general linux channel will be able to provide an answer, since sshd isnt exactly specific to ubuntu
there are some windows clients that work like screen
they run a daemon and the client connects to that daemon that does the ssh work
I didn't say you where talking about screen
re-read what I said
I said there are some clients that act LIKE screen
i have not yet responding to you
in that the front end you see isn't actually doing the work , the application daemon is
i am pretty sure theres no daemon involved
contact the application vendor for an explination
my question is unrelated to the client, i want to know how sshd possibly allows this
you'll need to know how the client works to understand that
as I said it maybe running a daemon/service as some windows ssh clients do
finding out from the client vendor how it works is the first step
as i said, im pretty sure theres no daemon, i am looking at my process list now
sorry, I didn't know you could read instead all the applications binaries
ask the vendor how it works, once they explain how it works you can look at working out if this is a risk or not
then ask the client maker how it works and you can work out if it's an ssh security flaw, or just the client doing work for you and it's fine
